model_response.text: A team of researchers at Carnegie Mellon University has discovered a way to make pizzas that are nearly identical to the ones served at Naples, Italy, the birthplace of this beloved culinary delight. The team, led by Professor David J. Kirschner, used a combination of machine learning algorithms and a 3D-printing technique to recreate the intricate structures found in traditional Neapolitan pizzas.The pizzas were made with a special dough that was designed to mimic the properties of the dough used in traditional Neapolitan pizzas. The dough was printed into the desired shape and topped with a variety of ingredients, including mozzarella cheese, tomatoes, basil, and olive oil. The pizzas were then baked in a custom-built oven that was designed to replicate the conditions found in a traditional Neapolitan pizzeria.To achieve the perfect round shape, the pizzas were baked in a special drum-shaped oven that was modeled after the classic wood-fired ovens found in Naples. The oven was heated to a high temperature, which helped to cook the dough quickly and evenly.The team's method, called "3D printing with inkjet-like technology," allows for the precise placement of ingredients and toppings, resulting in pizzas that are almost identical in appearance and taste to those made by a professional Neapolitan pizzeria.
